DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
28th February 2020 

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE 

Italy health official notes total coronavirus cases have increased to 650. Germany's North Rhine-Westphalia's health ministry announced 14 new cases in the Heinsberg area. France's Health Minister said there are 38 confirmed coronavirus cases in the country, says they are ready for an epidemic with 138 medical facilities ready. (Newswires) The first case of Coronavirus has been diagnosed in Northern Ireland, the BBC understands. (BBC)

US VP Pence said the best estimate is that the threat from COVID19 to the public remains low. (Newswires)

FDA monitoring supply chains, said it is not aware of any shortages of medical products, including drugs or devices, due to the outbreak; adds outbreak will likely affect medical supply chains in the US. (Newswires)

California Governor said they are reportedly monitoring 8.5k people for coronavirus in CA, notes they spoke with CDC about testing protocols and was assured they would be advanced with urgency, but CA only has a few hundred testing kits. California Governor Newsom also announced 33 people have tested positive for the coronavirus and 5 have moved out of state. (Newswires) New York State Health Department says 700 people in the state have been asked to voluntarily self-isolate for two weeks due to coronavirus, according to Breaking911. (Twitter) CDC Director says the CDC revised its case definition for "persons under investigation" for the coronavirus. (Newswires)

China Global Times said COVID-19 could accelerate the ongoing trend of shifting certain production away from China to Southeast Asia, according to industry insiders. (Global Times)

WHO Tederos said we are at a decisive point in the coronavirus epidemic; adds virus is not influenza, and with the right measures it can be contained; says no country should assume it will not get cases, would be a fatal mistake. (Newswires)

US House Speaker Pelosi said zero or low interest loans for small business are being discussed as a part of a fiscal coronavirus package. (Newswires) US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said he think the full Senate will take up funding legislation for the coronavirus within the next two weeks. (Newswires)

EU mulls support measures for sectors hit by COVID-19, including tourism and auto sectors, according to the EU industry commissioner; measures may be decided on in a months time. (Newswires) Germany government considering stimulus programme in case coronavirus hits the economy hard, Handelsblatt reports; Govt is considering various scenarios; plan should be ready in a few days, according to the report (Handelsblatt)

ECB President Lagarde said ECB monitoring coronavirus very carefully but it was not yet at the stage where it would have a lasting impact on inflation and therefore, does not require a monetary policy response. (Newswires)ECB's Holzmann said the coronavirus is no catastrophe for the economy, dramatic correction to the ECB projections is unlikely. (Newswires)

Germany Economy Minister said not planning a fiscal plan in the 'classic sense' to deal with the coronavirus; will have intense talks with Finance Minister Scholz regarding pulling forward individual economic measures. (Newswires)

IMF are likely to cut its global growth outlook in the next world economic outlook amid coronavirus, according to a spokesman. (Newswires)

Japanese PM Abe is to prepare legislation to reduce the economic impact from coronavirus. Japanese PM Abe has requested that all elementary, junior and high schools in Japan close from March 2nd until Spring Break (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Huawei Chair said group still able to deliver on time, despite Coronavirus. (Newswires)

UK/EU

ECB's Lane said more widespread contagion and a longer interruption in normal activity constitute additional downside risks to near-term projections. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte said we must work side by side to ensure a level playing field in talks between the EU and UK after a meeting with French President Macron. (Newswires)

EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier said negotiations with the UK will be difficult and short, as it is the UK's choice to leave at year-end. (Newswires)

ECB's Schnabel said that nobody knows where the reversal rate is and it is not clear if we have reached it. (Newswires)

BoE’s Cunliffe said the UK has weak domestic inflation, despite domestic cost pressures; question is how much of weak UK domestic inflation is cyclical against structural

UK Mandate: UK willing to trade on a no-deal basis with the EU if trade talks fail, want equivalent settlements to be carried out by June. (Newswires)

Data Recap

- EU Business Climate (Feb) -0.04 vs. Exp. -0.28 (Prev. -0.23, Rev. -0.19) (Newswires)

- EU Economic Sentiment (Feb) 103.5 vs. Exp. 102.8 (Prev. 102.8, Rev. 102.6)

COMMODITIES

Russian Energy Minister Novak said Russia wants to continue cooperation with Saudi within the OPEC+ and bilaterally. (Newswires)

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said OPEC+ are showing renewed commitment to reaching the accord, noted next week's meeting is to go ahead as scheduled. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Russian state TV said Turkish military planes are firing on Russian planes in Idlib, Syria, using shoulder-fired missiles. (Newswires)

Russian Kremlin denies that President Putin will be meeting with Turkish President Erdogan to discuss Syria on March 5th, despite claims from Erdogan. (Newswires)

32 Turkish soldiers were reportedly killed in the bombing of the Russian air Force in northern Syria, according to Kann News Amichai Stein. (Kann)

US

US Fed's Evans (non-voter, dove) regarding monetary policy, said we only have so much ammunition but if circumstances require additional accommodation we do have that capacity, adds policy is pretty well positioned for the risks that we have seen coming. Evans said when rates are near zero the Fed must commit to “extraordinary accommodation”. On inflation goal, says targeting an inflation range is harder to communicate than aiming for a point target. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans said looking for real economic impact from the coronavirus is the first thing to be considered, it is too early to tell if its growth forecast will be cut, and that it is going to take some time for the effects to show. (Newswires)

Data recap

- US Durable Goods (Jan) -0.2% vs. Exp. -1.5% (Prev. 2.4%, Rev. 2.9%) (Newswires)

- US Initial Jobless Claims w/e 219k vs. Exp. 212.0k (Prev. 210.0k, Rev. 211k)

- US GDP 2nd Estimate (Q4) 2.1% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.1%)

MARKET RECAP

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLE 3+ TICKS HIGHER AT 133-14. It was another choppy session for the TPLEX, which has ultimately seen yields in the shorter part of the curve fall by around 4.5bps, while the longer end was down by just under 1bps, at settlement; the shape of the curve, however, was steeper to the tune of 1-3bps. It was, of course, COVID19 headlines that were dictating the action, and the curve was influencing the FX space via the rate differential channel, which subsequently saw the USD come under pressure, particularly against the JPY. The US sold 7-year notes in an unspectacular auction, which tailed by 1.4bps, though cover had firmed versus recent averages. For now, Fed officials seem to be comfortable monitoring the risks, although markets seem to be somewhat less patient, and have priced in nearly three rate cuts through the end of this year. Analysts have said that whether this transpires on not will likely depend on the speed of the normalisation, and what actions US corporates could take in response (cutting guidance has been seen, but some have warned they may be far more worried by job cuts).

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -4.43%, DJ -4.4% at 25,760, Nasdaq -4.6% at 8566 * STOCK SPECIFICS: US equities traded heavily in the red once again with weekly losses on track for its worst performance since 2008. Microsoft (MSFT) were hit as it cut its Q3 personal computing segment revenue guidance due to coronavirus, sees supply chain returning to normal operations at a slower pace than previously expected. JP Morgan analyst Mark Murphy highlighted it is not a demand issue and the segment is its least strategic segment, noting all other segment guidance is unchanged. However, RBC note the worst scenario is a possible EPS decline of 21%. PayPal (PYPL) also issued updated guidance, where it expects Q1 revenue towards lower end of its previous guided USD 4.78-4.84bln range as a result of the coronavirus; note competitor Mastercard (MA) also recently cut its guidance. Gilead (GILD) traded higher as it initiated two Phase III studies of investigational antiviral Remdesivir for the treatment of coronavirus, with studies in Asian countries to being in March. Of note for food delivery names (GRUB, UBER) NYC council is considering a package of bills aimed at how much delivery companies can charge restaurants, and elsewhere in the space, DoorDash formally filed draft IPO documents with the SEC.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 27th February 2020: Virus uncertainty whacks risk again, stocks go into correction
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, dollar down, crude down
  • REAR VIEW: Virus fears hit risk assets again; ECB, Fed officials in wait and see; more solid housing data; US GDP headline unrevised, details not so great.
  • COMING UP:   Data: US PCE, adv goods trade balance, UoM, Chicago PMI. Canada GDP & German CPI. Speakers: Fed’s Mester and Bullard, BoE’s Haldane & Cunliffe, ECB’s Weidmann, Supply: 2-year auction from Japan.

* MARKET WRAP: Stocks have endured another day of selling, seeing the major three bourses fall into technical ‘correction territory’, with the narrative remaining uncertainty about the impact of the COVID19's spread. More cases have been reported in Europe, and even in the US, California said it has some 8400 people on its monitoring list. There were fresh record lows for 10-year and 30-year bond yields, while the VIX scaled 37. Some made the case that technical factors helped support SPX rising off lows (the folks at JPM argued on Wednesday that systematic selling and option hedging as well as poor liquidity was a major driver of downside, and argued that a short-term bounce was more likely than not). Central bank officials, however, do not seem in a rush to act; both ECB and Fed policymakers have indicated that they are monitoring the situation, but have appeared to suggest that policy settings are right for now (Lagarde was on that page today from the ECB, while a number of influential Fed officials have said as much recently) indicating monetary authorities are in no rush to give a nod to dovish market pricing (market has now almost completely priced in three Fed rate cuts in 2020). The bias clearly is to the downside, with desks now questioning how low we can go. Goldman Sachs today lowered its SPX target to 2,900, and provided scenario analysis which showed that in the event that the US entered a recession, the SPX would be unlikely to bounce back to the 3,400 level it sees in its upside scenarios; GS said to look for the S&P 500 forward P/E multiple to decline to 15x, implying another approximately 20% loss by end the year, at 2450. Meanwhile, the data slate was again decent today, with headline GDP unrevised at 2.1% in Q4 (under the bonnet, details weren't so great), while pending homes sales saw an upside surprise.

* FED: Fed's Evans (non-voter, dove) said looking for real economic impact from the coronavirus is the first thing to be considered, it is too early to tell if its growth forecast will be cut, and that it is going to take some time for the effects to show. Evans has not yet seen data indicating impact from coronavirus on trade flows between China and US, and is looking at whether lending behaviour is impacted, and for the moment, lending seems to be taking place at reasonable levels.

* US Q4 GDP (S): Headline GDP in Q4 was unrevised at 2.1%. Oxford economics said that while the data gives the impression of an economy chugging along at a 2.0% growth rate, the underlying details were softer, and the data represents the pre-COVID19 outbreak, suggesting some downside ahead. OxEco notes that around three-quarters of the GDP growth was a result of the temporary collapse in imports, while business investment contracted sharply, and consumers spent more cautiously. "The most recent three quarters mark the economy’s worst performance since the 2016 slump, and, stripping out trade, inventories and government spending, final sales to domestic purchasers rose only 1.3% – the weakest advance since 2015." Meanwhile, the headline PCE and core PCE prices advanced much less than anticipated in Q4, rising 1.3% Y/Y (-0.3ppt) and 1.2% Y/Y (-0.1ppt), with headline inflation stuck at a modest 1.4% Y/Y and core inflation slipped back to 1.6% Y/Y. "Tightening financial conditions have added a new dimension to the coronavirus outbreak. The economic impact to the US and global economy was believed to be mostly contained last week, but rising volatility, plunging stock prices, and a strengthening dollar will likely exacerbate the economic shock on the US economy." In terms of the policy implications, the GDP report is of course backward-looking, and OxEco does not think it will sway the Fed in terms of its assessment of activity and monetary policy, "but on the margin, downwardly revised inflation, disappointing growth and tightening financial conditions in the wake of the coronavirus will lead to a Fed rate cut in April, or even March, if financial conditions deteriorate materially."

* US PENDING HOME SALES: Another decent housing data print, with pending home sales surging by 5.0% in January, topping the Street's 3.0% estimate, and reversing December's fall. "The January rebound confirms our suspicions that the 4.3% December drop was due to seasonal adjustment problems over the holiday," Pantheon Macroeconomics said, "still, the very modest net gain over the two months is smaller than we expected, given low and falling mortgage rates and the long period of much warmer-than-usual winter weather." Pantheon notes that the data series is noisy, however, the outlook for the housing sector remains very favourable, provided the US does not suffer a serious COVID19 outbreak.

* US DURABLE GOODS: Durable goods orders declined by 0.2% in January, better than the consensus -1.5%. The ex-defence measure was 3.6%, rising from the -2.4%, and the ex-transport measure printed 0.9%, topping the 0.2% consensus. Capital Economics said that durable goods orders were held down last month by a plunge in volatile defence orders, but the surge in underlying capital goods orders and shipments suggests business equipment investment growth is beginning to rebound. "That's another clear sign the Fed's rate cuts are feeding through to stronger economic growth, but that recovery would be quickly curtailed in the event of a widespread domestic coronavirus outbreak," it adds.

* ECB: ECB's Lagarde told the FT that the coronavirus did not currently warrant a monetary policy response from the ECB. ECB's Schnabel said the ECB was "very worried" about the COVID-19 and it is raising uncertainty to a large degree, and that if the virus proves to be more persistent, the ECB will not be able to look through it. Meanwhile, she said that price pressures remain subdued, and that medium-term horizon was now longer than had previously been; there was some debate over whether the Bank should look at other survey indicators of inflation expectations, she said. On asset prices, Schnabel thinks asset prices should not be included in inflation measures. On the scope to reduce rates further, Schnabel said that nobody knows where the reversal rate is, and it is not clear if we have reached it. ECB's Holzmann said the coronavirus is no catastrophe for the economy, dramatic correction to the ECB projections is unlikely.

* GERMAN FISCAL STIMULUS: German government is considering stimulus programme in case coronavirus hits the economy hard, Handelsblatt reported; the government is mulling various scenarios, and a plan should be ready in a few days. Germany's Economy minister Altmaier, however, said the government was not planning a fiscal plan in the 'classic sense' to deal with the coronavirus, and said he sees only a limited impact of global growth from the virus, but much will depend on how things develop. He will have intense talks with finance minister Scholz regarding pulling forward individual economic measures. At the moment, Altmaier said, there are no major disruptions to orders or to supply chains in Germany, though the government stood ready to adjust size of any financial measures as needed. Altmaier also said the government must discuss measures to reduce tax measures for companies.

* BREXIT: The UK published its negotiating mandate for trade talks with the EU, which were largely in line with expectations. The UK is willing to trade on a no-deal basis with the EU if trade talks fail, and it wants equivalent settlements to be carried out by June. The UK does not want a role for the ECJ in any dispute mechanism, and the UK should not be required to follow EU standards and should not -- in any manner -- constrict tax sovereignty. UK also said that, in line with the EU-Canadian agreement precedent, the deal should recognise the right of each party to set their own labour priorities and adopt or modify tax laws, and any agreement should include reciprocal commitments not to weaken/reduce the level of protection was is provided by labour laws/standards to encourage trade and/or investment. The UK wants streamlined customs arrangements, covering all trade in EU goods, and it will not link access to its fishing waters to access EU markets. Responding, the EU's Brexit negotiator Barnier said negotiations with the UK will be difficult and short, given it is the UK's choice to leave at year-end, while also adding that the equivalence regime for financial services is not part of UK/EU negotiations. Separately, UK Chancellor Sunak has ordered additional set of forecasts from OBR, to be published on 13th March; OBR will have a "limited" update on 11th March Budget.

* AUSSIE CAPEX: Capex data overnight was expected to rebound in Q4, though declined by 2.8% Q/Q (exp +0.5%). However, analysts were encouraged by the forward-looking measures, with mining capex intentions likely to drive growth this year and next. Nevertheless, non-mining capex intentions augur a contraction in capex in FY 2020, Goldman Sachs said. "Overall we viewed today's data as soft and lower our 4Q 2019 GDP tracker -10bps to +0.4% Q/Q (due next Wednesday), we note this is broadly in line with the RBA's latest forecasts."

* BOK: The Bank of Korea kept rates unchanged at 1.25%, against the building expectations of a rate cut. With that said, there were two dovish dissenters calling for a 25bps reduction. The growth projection - a useful indicator in the current coronavirus environment - was trimmed by 0.2ppts to 2.1%, a more benign downgrade than many desks had anticipated, although there is a suggestion it could be lowered again when more information about the virus and its containment are known. The Governor explained the BOK's decision by noting the uncertainty on how long and how bad the virus develops, while also noting some financial stability concerns about the impact of lower rates on the housing market; additionally, the BOK is coordinating with the government on providing micro measures. The governor did however suggest that the Bank's on hold decision was based on the assumption that the impact from the virus does not extend into Q2. Desks suggested that with the BOK in data dependent mode, the case for a rate cut at the April confab will grow, unless the virus becomes contained very quickly.

* WTI (J0) SETTLES USD 1.64 LOWER AT USD 47.09/BBL; BRENT (K0) SETTLED USD 1.08 LOWER USD 51.73/BBL: WTI and Brent continued to decline amid broader coronavirus concerns and the potential impact on demand. WTI continued its march beneath USD 50/bbl, to lows of 45.88 from highs early in the morning, and Brent briefly fell beneath USD 51/bbl before paring back to above USD 53/bbl. Sources suggested that Saudi Arabia is to cut March oil supply to China by 500k BPD due to the slow demand. On OPEC+, OPEC Secretary General Barkindo noted that there appears to be “renewed commitment” to reaching a deal and that next week’s meeting is to go ahead as expected, and Russia’s Energy Minister Novak noted Russia wants to continue cooperation with Saudi within OPEC+ and bilaterally. Note, analysts at Citi say the recent price action may be helpful in either convincing Russia to accept the 600k BPD cut recommended by the JTC, or for OPEC+ to consider an even larger cut.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLE 3+ TICKS HIGHER AT 133-14. It was another choppy session for the TPLEX, which has ultimately seen yields in the shorter part of the curve fall by around 4.5bps, while the longer end was down by just under 1bps, at settlement; the shape of the curve, however, was steeper to the tune of 1-3bps. It was, of course, COVID19 headlines that were dictating the action, and the curve was influencing the FX space via the rate differential channel, which subsequently saw the USD come under pressure, particularly against the JPY. The US sold 7-year notes in an unspectacular auction, which tailed by 1.4bps, though cover had firmed versus recent averages. For now, Fed officials seem to be comfortable monitoring the risks, although markets seem to be somewhat less patient, and have priced in nearly three rate cuts through the end of this year. Analysts have said that whether this transpires on not will likely depend on the speed of the normalisation, and what actions US corporates could take in response (cutting guidance has been seen, but some have warned they may be far more worried by job cuts).

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -4.43%, DJ -4.4% at 25,760, Nasdaq -4.6% at 8566

* STOCK SPECIFICS: US equities traded heavily in the red once again with weekly losses on track for its worst performance since 2008. Microsoft (MSFT) were hit as it cut its Q3 personal computing segment revenue guidance due to coronavirus, sees supply chain returning to normal operations at a slower pace than previously expected. JP Morgan analyst Mark Murphy highlighted it is not a demand issue and the segment is its least strategic segment, noting all other segment guidance is unchanged. However, RBC note the worst scenario is a possible EPS decline of 21%. PayPal (PYPL) also issued updated guidance, where it expects Q1 revenue towards lower end of its previous guided USD 4.78-4.84bln range as a result of the coronavirus; note competitor Mastercard (MA) also recently cut its guidance. Gilead (GILD) traded higher as it initiated two Phase III studies of investigational antiviral Remdesivir for the treatment of coronavirus, with studies in Asian countries to being in March. Of note for food delivery names (GRUB, UBER) NYC council is considering a package of bills aimed at how much delivery companies can charge restaurants, and elsewhere in the space, DoorDash formally filed draft IPO documents with the SEC.

*EARNINGS: Best Buy (BBY) was supported by strong beats on its earnings report, while also reporting solid guidance, gains, however, were capped amid the soured risk sentiment. Booking Holdings (BKNG) reported solid EPS and revenue, although only provided poor guidance.  Marriot (MAR) traded firmer from an EPS beat, while noting its guidance does not include the impact of the coronavirus as it cannot fully estimate the nominal amount.  Anaplan (PLAN) fell ~20% after forecasting its operating margin to be -17.5 to -18.5%, meanwhile announcing its Chief Growth Officer has stepped down, and it will not be refilling the road. Etsy (ETSY) surged over 10% following a strong earnings beat and optimistic guidance.

* FX WRAP:  As US yields were crushed again, rate differentials have moved against the dollar (DXY has settled around 98.50), and to the benefit of the yen (USDJPY back under 110.00). The EUR (briefly topping 1.10) has benefitted from shorts continuing to cover, unwinding EMFX carry, while month-end factors were also said to support. GBP has been fairly resilient and is closing out the day flat/slightly lower, with month-end factors in EURGBP playing a role, while punchy Brexit rhetoric reminds us how contentious trade talks will be. Activity currency (AUD, NZD) are higher, but that is more about the USD than any constructive macro outlook. EMFX have endured another torrid session. Commodity FX could not benefit from the dollar downside, with crude sliding.

subject: US T-Note futures (H0) settle 3+ ticks higher at 133-14
analysis_details: It was another choppy session for the TPLEX, which has ultimately seen yields in the shorter part of the curve fall by around 4.5bps, while the longer end was down by just under 1bps, at settlement; the shape of the curve, however, was steeper to the tune of 1-3bps. It was, of course, COVID19 headlines that were dictating the action, and the curve was influencing the FX space via the rate differential channel, which subsequently saw the USD come under pressure, particularly against the JPY. The US sold 7-year notes in an unspectacular auction, which tailed by 1.4bps, though cover had firmed versus recent averages. For now, Fed officials seem to be comfortable monitoring the risks, although markets seem to be somewhat less patient, and have priced in nearly three rate cuts through the end of this year. Analysts have said that whether this transpires on not will likely depend on the speed of the normalisation, and what actions US corporates could take in response (cutting guidance has been seen, but some have warned they may be far more worried by job cuts).

subject: Daily FX Wrap: super Thursday for safe havens, but bleak for the Buck and EMs
content:
DXY

Not quite freefall, but a pretty steep and deeper retreat from 99.125 through Fib and chart support just ahead of 98.500 to 98.355 for the Dollar index as the US Treasury curve flipped back to bull-flattening mode amidst an acceleration of risk aversion due to the coronavirus. In sum, the contamination tally and death toll continue to rise, with the outbreak reaching more new countries almost by the day, while a confirmed case in the US was classified as a potential community spread. In the current clime, US data (and other for that matter) hardly even registered, but for the record durable goods and pending home sales beat consensus and the 2nd look at Q4 GDP unrevised vs a modest jobless claims miss.

EUR/CHF/AUD/NZD/JPY 

The Euro has gleaned the most momentum from the Greenback’s demise, technical impulses and its primary status as a go to or carry currency when capital is flooding out of EM currencies. Indeed, Eur/Usd reclaimed 1.0900 before scaling a series of resistance levels, an option expiry and more upside chart points on the way to a new multi-week high just above 1.1000. Meanwhile, the Franc rebounded around a big figure vs the Buck around 0.9700, but could not keep pace with the single currency as the Eur/Chf cross breached 1.0650 compared to sub-1.0600 a couple of times recently (before some verbal if not physical SNB intervention). Elsewhere, even the Aussie and Kiwi took advantage of their US counterpart’s misfortune despite clear and officially acknowledged threats to the Antipodean economies from the aforementioned Chinese COVID-19 outbreak, with Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd back up towards 0.6600 and over 0.6325 respectively. Last, but not least in terms of volatility, the Yen straddled 110.00 for the most part and mainly above during EU trade on intermittent nCoV headlines and related fluctuations in sentiment following dovish BoJ commentary and in advance of a host of Japanese data.

NOK/SEK/GBP/CAD

The Norwegian Krona was undermined early on by weaker than expected retail sales, but then sunk to record lows vs the Euro alongside crude prices, in contrast to the Swedish Crown that was propped to a degree by improvements in sentiment indicators and above forecast consumption figures. Meanwhile, Cable and the Pound more generally was rattled by confirmation of a pretty rigid UK mandate for Brexit trade talks, as Cable recoiled from just shy of 1.2950 to circa 1.2860 and Eur/Gbp rose more than 100 pips from around 0.8430 with added impetus via further RHS month end activity. A moderately narrower than anticipated Canadian current account deficit hardly helped the Loonie as the slide in oil kept Usd/Cad in the upper reaches of a 1.3316-74 range.

EM

As noted above, regional currencies have endured a torrid session against the backdrop of heightened China epidemic concerns, but the Lira and Rouble were also pressured by reports of an escalation of military action in Syria, while the Real hit a fresh all time low around 4.5000 and the Mexican Peso depreciated in wake of a rise in unemployment rather than Banxico rhetoric.

Grubhub (GRUB) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) / Uber (UBER) (Industrials/Road & Rail) – NYC council is reportedly considering a package of bills aimed at how much delivery companies can charge restaurants, according to NY Times.

JetBlue (JBLU) (Industrials/Airlines) announced it will suspend change and cancel fees for new flight bookings from today until March 11th as it reassures customers that they will not be charged for cancellations in relation to the coronavirus.

Keurig Dr Pepper Inc (KDP) (Consumer Staples/Beverages) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.35 (exp. 0.35), Revenue 2.93bln (exp. 2.96bln). FY20 adj. EPS view 1.38-1.40 (exp. 1.40), FY20 net sales growth of 3-4%. Qiagen (QGEN) (Health Care/Life Sciences Tools & Services) announced it has shipped newly developed coronavirus test kits to four hospitals in China.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 27th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) cuts Q3 personal computing segment revenue guidance due to coronavirus, sees supply chain returning to normal operations at a slower pace than previously expected
  • PayPal (PYPL) (Information Technology/Data Processing & Outsourced Services) expects Q1 revenue towards lower end of its previous guided USD 4.78-4.84bln range as a result of the coronavirus
  • Best Buy Co. Inc. (BBY) (Consumer Discretionary/Computer & Electronics Retail) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 2.90 (exp. 2.75), Revenue 15.2bln (exp. 15.05bln), enterprise SSS +3.2%; Q1 EPS view 1.00-1.05 (exp. 1.01), Q1 revenue view 9.1-9.2bln (exp. 9.28bln), SSS view 0-1%. FY20 EPS view 6.10-6.30 (exp. 6.25) raises quarterly dividend by 10% to 0.55/shr

27th February 2020

DOW

Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) is to lose two senior executives, Forlenza and Pasmooij, in the manufacturing, supply chain and operations group who were key in some of its major device production. Forlenza has retired and Pasmooij is in talks about leaving the company in the short term, according to people familiar with the matter.

Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) cuts Q3 personal computing segment revenue guidance due to coronavirus, sees supply chain returning to normal operations at a slower pace than previously expected. JP Morgan analyst Mark Murphy highlights it is not a demand issue and the segment is its least strategic segment, noting all other segment guidance is unchanged. However, RBC note the worst scenario is a possible EPS decline of 21%.

NASDAQ 100

Biomarin Pharmaceutical Inc (BMRN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.08 (exp. -0.06), Revenue 0.454bln (exp. .46bln). FY20 revenue view 1.95-2.05bln (exp. 1.95bln).

NetEase Inc (NTES) (Communication Services/Entertainment) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. income per ADS 4.07 (prev. 5.26), Revenue 2.26bln (exp. 2.19bln).

Marriott Int'l. (MAR) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Resorts & Cruise Lines) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 1.57 (exp. 1.47), Revenue 5.37bln (exp. 5.48bln). FY20 EPS view 6.30-6.53 (exp. 6.47). Q4 comparable systemwide constant dollar RevPAR: worldwide +1.1%, Ex-North America +1.5%, North America +0.9%. Q1 comparable systemwide RevPAR view +1-2%. Notes the coronavirus to date has primary affected its Asia Pacific region but it cannot fully estimate the financial impact on its outlook, therefore its guidance does not reflect the coronavirus.

Stars Group Inc (TSG) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & leisure) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.49 (exp. 0.41), Revenue 0.688bln (exp. .67bln).

Booking Holdings Inc (BKNG) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 23.30 (exp. 22.04), Revenue 3.30bln (exp. 3.28bln).; Q1 forecast - EPS 9.05-9.65 (exp. 11.74) and Adj. EBIT 5.60-5.90bln (exp. 7.06bln).

Gilead Sciences (GILD) (Health Care/Biotechnology) has initiated two Phase III studies of investigational antiviral Remdesivir for the treatment of coronavirus - studies in Asian countries to being in March.

PayPal (PYPL) (Information Technology/Data Processing & Outsourced Services) expects Q1 revenue towards lower end of its previous guided USD 4.78-4.84bln range as a result of the coronavirus; note competitor Mastercard (MA) also recently cut its guidance.

S&P 500

Ameren Corp (AEE) (Utilities/Multi-Utilities) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.38 (exp. 0.31), Revenue 1.32bln (exp. 1.6bln). FY20 EPS view 3.40-3.60 (exp. 3.46).

ANSYS (ANSS) (Information Technology/Application Software) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 2.24 (exp. 1.98), Revenue 0.4925bln (exp. .47bln). Q1 EPS view 0.75-0.88 (exp. 1.98bln), revenue 0.30-0.32bln (exp. 0.36bln). FY20 EPS view 6.19-6.71bln (exp. 6.76bln), revenue view 1.64-1.7bln (exp. 1.68bln).

Apache Corporation (APA) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.08 (exp. -0.06), revenue 1.70bln (exp. 1.61bln). Plans to invest USD 1.6-1.9bln in upstream oil and gas this year, -36% Y/Y.

Best Buy Co. Inc. (BBY) (Consumer Discretionary/Computer & Electronics Retail) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 2.90 (exp. 2.75), Revenue 15.2bln (exp. 15.05bln), enterprise SSS +3.2%; Q1 EPS view 1.00-1.05 (exp. 1.01), Q1 revenue view 9.1-9.2bln (exp. 9.28bln), SSS view 0-1%. FY20 EPS view 6.10-6.30 (exp. 6.25) raises quarterly dividend by 10% to 0.55/shr. Fy21 enterprise revenue view 43.3-44.3bln (exp. 44.22bln), FY21 enterprise SSS 0-2%. Material supply chain disruption due to coronavirus but it cannot solve the problem this year.

CBRE Group (CBRE) (Real Estate/Real Estate Services) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 1.32 (exp. 1.35), Revenue 7.11bln (exp. 6.91bln). FY20 Adj. EPS view 4.05-4.25 (exp. 4.07).

Discovery Inc (DISCA) (Communication Services/Media) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.98 (exp. 0.93), Revenue 2.874bln (exp. 2.87bln).

Eversource Energy (ES) (Utilities/Multi-Utilities) announced an agreement with NiSource (NI) to acquire Massachusetts natural gas assets of Columbia Gas from NI for USD 1.1bln.

FLIR Systems (FLIR) (Information Technology/Electronic Equipment & Instruments) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.55 (exp. 0.62), Revenue 0.489bln (exp. .5bln), announced it is restructuring by consolidating three businesses, to two.

Lilly (Eli) & Co. (LLY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced FDA committee voted in favour of CYRAMZA/ramucirumab plus erlotinib demonstrated positive benefit/risk profile for patients with non-small cell lung cancer.

Mylan N.V. (MYL) and Pfizer (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced it has finalised a board of directors for Viatris, the new company formed from the combination of Mylan and PFE’s Upjohn, which is expected to go ahead in the middle of 2020, dependent upon regulatory approvals, Mylan shareholder approval, and the satisfaction of other customary closing conditions. Sanjeev Narula, CFO of Upjohn will become CEO of the combined company.

analysis_details: • Follows on from both the EU and UK releasing their trade negotiation mandates this week; with the UK's taking a fairly hardline or uncompromising stance going into the talks

subject: NY Fed 14-day term repo operation oversubcribed; accepts USD 25bln of USD 46.3bln of offers
EU mulls support measures for sectors hit by COVID-19, including tourism and auto sectors, according to the EU industry commissioner; measures may be decided on in a months time
Turkish Defense Minister says discussing opening air space with Russia for armed and unarmed drones in Syria
analysis_details: Stratfor explains the Syrian government's offensive against rebel forces in Idlib province carries significant risks for Turkey and Russia. "Ankara supports many of the rebel groups in Idlib and wants to prevent another flow of Syrian refugees into Turkey, Moscow backs the Syrian offensive," and adds that "each wants to avoid a direct confrontation while deterring the other's intervention. The stakes are high. And standing by is the United States, ready to exploit the rift to try to bring Turkey back into its fold."

subject: Scotiabank FX Daily - USD Falls Broadly as Risk Aversion Deepens
content:
•   USD weak versus G-10 on the day as US yields slide.
  •   CAD treads water versus USD but remains vulnerable on weak crude.
  •   EUR short-covering rally extends as markets exit EUR-funded carry trades.
  •   GBP weak on belligerent UK trade negotiating stance.
  •   JPY steady near 110 as CHF picks up “refuge” mantle.
  •   AUD modestly firmer versus soft USD; Aus sovereign yields reach record low.
  •   MXN extends losses on market volatility; Mex unemployment jumps to 3.79%.

subject: Germany government considering stimulus programme in case coronavirus hits the economy hard, Handelsblatt reports; Govt is considering various scenarios; plan should be ready in a few days, according to the report
UK Chancellor Sunak has ordered additional set of forecasts from OBR, to be published on 13th March; OBR will have a "limited" update on 11th March Budget
EU's Barnier says equivalence regime for financial services is not part of UK/EU negotiations
Best Buy Co Inc (BBY) Q4 19 (USD): Adj EPS 2.90 (exp. 2.75), Revenue 15.2bln (exp. 15.05bln); raises quarterly dividend by 10% to 0.55/shr
Sempra Energy (SRE) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 1.55 (exp. 1.48), Revenue 2.94bln (exp. 3.59bln)
Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 27th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Sentiment remains affixed to the coronavirus, with European bourses down and US equity futures currently posting losses of 1%
  • South Korea reported over 500 more cases of new coronavirus thus far, taking the total to 1766; with increases in multiple countries
  • Italian coronavirus cases may be inflated due to testing errors, WHO Official; did coincide with a mild uptick in sentiment
  • Microsoft have cut their Q3 personal computing guidance and supply chain normalisation due to the coronavirus
  • GBP is subdued as the UK’s EU negotiating mandate takes a hard-line/uncompromising initial stance
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Durable Goods, GDP (2nd Estimate), PCE Prices (Prelim), Pending Sales, Japanese CPI, Unemployment Rate & Retail Sales, ECB’s Lane, de Guindos, Fed’s Mester & Evans, Supply from US

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US President Trump said the risk to the American people from the virus is very low, we are ready to act, adapt and do whatever we have to, If congress wants to allocate more than USD 2.5bln for coronavirus, we’ll take it. Trump added that he has spoken to doctors and believe that the vaccine can be developed rapidly. The President announced that he will be putting VP Mike Pence in charge of US response to coronavirus. Trump acknowledged that Chinese President Xi is working very hard on the virus situation but noted that coronavirus could impact US GDP. US President Trump reiterated he thinks the stock markets will recover and puts some blame for the stock rout on the US Democratic debate. (Newswires) Trump Administration sees coronavirus as a serious threat with a fatality rate comparable to the flu, sources say. (Twitter) US Pentagon is mulling whether it may need additional funding to deal with the spread of COVID-19. (Newswires) US VP Pence is to lead a task force meeting on Thursday at 14:30ET/19:30GMT. (Newswires)

US National Institute of Allergy Infection Diseases Director gave a timeframe of 1 to 1.5 years for a usable vaccine. US Secretary of Health says we can expect to see more cases in the US, the degree of virus risk has the potential to change quickly. (Newswires)

First US coronavirus case of unknown origin confirmed in North California (Washington Post) CDC said that the COVID-19 case in California of unknown origin could be an instance of community spread, which would be the first time this has happened in the US. (Newswires)

South Korea reported over 500 more cases of new coronavirus thus far on February 26 vs. a total 284 on February 25; total cases now at 1766 and a 13th coronavirus-related death reported. (Yonhap) South Korea and US combined military exercises will be postponed "until further notice" amid coronavirus fears. (Yonhap) Japan's ruling party is reportedly considering an extra budget to tackle the virus outbreak, according to Nikkei. (Nikkei) China's Wang Yi has offered further help to Japan over virus controls. (Newswires) Germany has reported 9 new cases of coronavirus so far on February 26, whilst Demark reported its first case, according to BNO Newsroom. (Twitter)

Italian coronavirus cases may be inflated due to testing errors, WHO Official. (Newswires)

-        Italian think tank Prometeia has lowered its 2020 GDP estimate to -0.3% in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires)

China's Hubei province reported 409 new coronavirus cases and 26 additional deaths as of February 26 vs. 401 additional cases and 52 additional deaths on February 25, Total cases 65596 and deaths 2641. China reported an additional 433 coronavirus cases and 29 additional deaths as of February 26 vs. 406 additional cases and 52 deaths on February 25; Total China cases 78497 vs. Prev. 78064; Deaths 2744 vs. Prev. 2715. (Newswires)

PBoC says they are to ensure ample liquidity via RRR cuts in appropriate time, will increase re-lending and re-discount credit; Will look into, and instigate, policies to support the capital replenishment of China's smaller lenders in order to aid the real-economy. (Newswires)

Japanese PM Abe has requested that all elementary, junior and high schools in Japan close from March 2nd until Spring Break. While, China are to postpone the re-opening of education facilities in principle, according to State TV. (Newswires)

US President Trump said now is not the right time to restrict travel from South Korea, Italy and other infected countries, but may impose restrictions at some point, but travel restrictions to China will not be loosened until the virus is no longer a problem. Trump said the US has plans on a larger scale quarantine if needed. (Newswires) US State Department raised the alert level for South Korea over the virus outbreak. (Newswires) IMF and World Bank are reportedly rethinking April 17-19 meeting amid coronavirus, according to sources. (Newswires)

Gilead (GILD) has initiated two Phase III studies of investigational antiviral Remdesivir for the treatment of coronavirus - studies in Asian countries to be in March. (Newswires) Kanagawa prefecture is said to have developed a faster virus test, according to TV Asahi. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly lower following a mixed Wall Street handover, as major indices faded gains heading into the latter part of the US session before the Dow and S&P dipped into negative territory – with the former’s losses tallying over 2000 points this week thus far. Furthermore, US equity futures trickled lower since reopen amid the rising virus cases outside China and with the first “community spread” reported in the States. ASX 200 (-0.8%) is mostly weighed on by its banking and base-metal miners, while some earnings-related movers were scattered across the index. Nikkei 225 (-2.1%) underperformed with downside led by manufacturing, automakers, and financials, whilst Panasonic shares slid over 4% after ending its solar partnership with Tesla. KOSPI (-0.7%) hit levels last seen in October last year as the index continued to be weighed on by the surging number of coronavirus cases in the country, alongside the surprise hold on rates by the BoK. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) joined the regional stock rout as the energy and entertainment names added further to the losses seen this week, whilst Shanghai Comp (+0.1%) showed resilience and bucked the trend despite yet another PBoC inaction, as the rate of virus deaths in the country eased, the rate new cases steadied, and with further pledges from China to cushion the virus impact and stem the contagion.

PBoC sets USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0215 vs. Exp. 7.0164 (Prev. 7.0126) (Newswires) PBOC skips open market operations for a daily net neutral position

The Bank of Korea surprisingly left its Base Rate on hold at 1.25% vs. expectations for a 25bps. The decision was not unanimous, prior dissenters Shin and Cho advocated a rate cut. The BoK also lowered its 2020 GDP forecast to 2.1% from 2.3%, whilst maintaining its inflation forecast for the year at 1.0%. BoK Governor Lee said the growth outlook assumes virus outbreak will not last too long, whilst also noting that South Korean Q1 growth could be negative. Governor Lee did state that the Central Bank has enough policy room to respond to growth risks if needed. Furthermore, the BoK stated they are to expand special loan programs by KRW 5tln to improve liquidity. (Newswires)

BoJ Board Member Kataoka said the BoJ is ready to ease without hesitation if needed, must deepen negative rates to make the shape of the yield curve more accommodative; Japan has no longer the momentum to reach its 2% goal. Kataoka added that there is room for BoJ to review its monetary policy framework and re-examine the effects of its policy and noted that risks to economy tilted to the downside. (Newswires)

New Zealand Annual Trade Balance (Jan) -3.87B (Prev. -4.31B, Rev. -4.46B) (Newswires) New Zealand Exports (Jan) 4.73B (Prev. 5.54B, Rev. 5.50B) New Zealand Imports (Jan) 5.07B (Prev. 5.0B, Rev. 5.12B)

S&P affirmed New Zealand rating at "AA"; outlook revised to "positive" from "stable". (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Mandate for EU trade negotiations: UK willing to trade on a no-deal basis with the EU if trade talks fail, want equivalent settlements to be carried out by June

-        Will be no role for the ECJ in any dispute mechanism; Should not require UK to follow EU standards

-        In line with the EU-Canadian agreement precedent, deal should recognise the right of each party to set their own labour priorities and adopt or modify tax laws

-        UK will not link access to its fishing waters to access EU markets

-        Should provide for streamlined customs arrangements covering all trade in EU goods

EU Consumer Confidence Final (Feb) -6.6 vs. Exp. -6.6 (Prev. -6.6, Rev. -8.1)

-        Economic Sentiment (Feb) 103.5 vs. Exp. 102.8 (Prev. 102.8, Rev. 102.6)

-        Industrial Sentiment (Feb) -6.1 vs. Exp. -7.3 (Prev. -7.3, Rev. -7.0)

-        Services Sentiment (Feb) 11.2 vs. Exp. 11.2 (Prev. 11.0)

-        Business Climate (Feb) -0.04 vs. Exp. -0.28 (Prev. -0.23, Rev. -0.19)

ECB's Schnabel says that price pressures remain subdued, and that medium-term horizon is longer than has previously been; the ECB is "very worried" about the COVID-19 and it is raising uncertainty to a large degree. Adds, that nobody knows where the reversal rate is and it is not clear if we have reached it; this rate is not one number, is constantly moving – tiering has created further space. (ECB)

BoE’s Cunliffe says the UK has weak domestic inflation, despite domestic cost pressures; question is how much of weak UK domestic inflation is cyclical against structural

-        Sees inflation coming from the UK labour market

-        Should not rush into radical conclusions regarding monetary policy framework, there is policy space

-        If we have a shock, policy space should be used rapidly in order to avoid any liquidity traps 

GEOPOLITICS 

Russian Kremlin denies that President Putin will be meeting with Turkish President Erdogan to discuss Syria on March 5th, despite claims from Erdogan. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Once again, it’s been a tough start to the session for European equities (Eurostoxx 50 -2.3%, FTSE 100 -1.9% and now in correction territory) as market sentiment is dictated by incremental newsflow surrounding COVID-19. Focus continues to reside on developments external to China with the further selling pressure being brought about by multiple updates including the potential first “community spread” case in the US, the mounting case count in South Korea and government’s across the globe lifting their threat levels over the virus. Despite comments from the WHO that the coronavirus case count might have been inflated in Italy by testing errors, markets have not been able to stage anything close to a meaningful recovery. From a sector standpoint, as has been the case throughout the week, selling has been relatively broad-based with only utility names holding up marginally better than their peers following earnings from Engie (+4%). Travel names continue to remain the ugly duckling in Europe with recent- cost-cutting measures across the sector unable to stop the rot; Tui -6.3%, easyJet -7.5%, Lufthansa -7.5%, RyanAir -7%, IAG -8%. Elsewhere, it’s been a busy morning of corporate updates with WPP (-14%) at the foot of the Stoxx 600  after a disappointing Q4 sales outturn, Belgian Heavyweight AB Inbev (-9.5%) are lower after warning on Q1 profits in the wake of COVID-19, whilst UK homebuilder Persimmon (-4.5%) lag peers after posting an annual decline in profits. To the upside, Carrefour (+3.5%) are firmer after announcing increased cost savings targets alongside earnings, Reckitt Benckiser (+2.5%) have reversed losses seen at the opening after taking a GBP 5bln impairment on Mead Johnson Nutrition and British American Tobacco (+1.5%) are showing mild gains after showing pretax profit and sales growth in its latest earnings update. Stateside, focus will be on Microsoft (-2.5% pre-market) after the Co. cut its Q3 personal computing segment revenue guidance due to coronavirus.

Microsoft (MSFT) cut its Q3 personal computing segment revenue guidance due to coronavirus, sees supply chain returning to normal operations at a slower pace than previously expected. (Newswires) For reference, Co. has a 4.2% weighting in the DJIA, 4.9% in the S&P and 11.3% in the Nasdaq; Co. shares fell 2% after-market

FX

USD - The Greenback has unwound all and more of its gains vs most G10 peers amidst ramped up Fed rate cut expectations on the ever-increasing spread of China’s COVID-19 epidemic to the point of pandemic proportions. The Buck’s retreat coincides with a marked rise in the number of suspected US cases and one confirmed in North Carolina from unknown origin that the CDC contends may constitute a community spread. In response, the DXY has reversed further below the 99.000 level to a 98.658 low and not far from Fib support at 98.550 that virtually coincides with another strong technical mark in the form of a late November 2019 high. Ahead, multiple US data releases and more Fed rhetoric, but for the time being it’s all about coronavirus and contagion.

EUR/NZD/CHF/AUD - The major beneficiaries of the aforementioned US Dollar demise, with the Euro embarking on a firmer recovery rally through 1.0900, 1.0926 resistance and a 1.0937 Fib before pulling up just ahead of 1.0950, a decent 1.0955 option expiry (1 bn) and another Fib at 1.0958. Meanwhile, the Kiwi and Aussie have both pared losses from sub-0.6300/0.6550 lows even though the RBNZ and NZ Finance Minister have warned of near term downside economic effects from the nCoV, with the former estimating a 0.3% point q/q hit to Q1 GDP, and Australia’s PM expressed concerns about a global pandemic that warrants action. In similar vein, the Franc has shrugged off latest dovish SNB commentary to a certain extent, as Usd/Chf slips closer to 0.9700 in contrast to Eur/Chf remaining above 1.0600 on the relative common currency strength noted above.

JPY - Volatile trade for the Yen around 110.00 vs the Greenback and within a 120.56-119.96 range against the Euro, as underlying safe-haven demand alongside dovish BoJ remarks propelled the Japanese unit to best levels before key chart support and psychological levels held. However, a raft of looming Japanese economic indicators should provide some fundamental direction, including CPI, jobs, IP and retail sales.

CAD/NOK/GBP/SEK - The Loonie is meandering either side of 1.3325 ahead of Canadian current account data and capped by another marked decline in crude, but showing a bit more resilience than the Norwegian Crown that has fallen below 10.2750 vs the Euro in wake of much weaker than forecast retail sales. Conversely, the Swedish Krona has been cushioned by encouraging sentiment indicators and wider trade surplus, with Eur/Sek retreating towards the bottom of 10.6125-5570 extremes. However, Sterling is back under pressure on a combination of bearish factors, as Cable reverses from around 1.2950 to 1.2870 or so and Eur/Gbp tests 0.8500 on heightened no deal Brexit prospects, more month end cross flows and elevated BoE easing expectations rather than actual MPC guidance via Cunliffe.

EM - Losses across the board on broad risk aversion, but with the Try also subject to further Syrian related angst as Russia refutes any meeting in early March and the Lira breaches a key mark (circa 6.1600 vs the Usd) that had been providing a buffer.

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

-        EUR/USD: 1.0820 (1.1BLN), 1.0900 (632M), 1.0915-25 (1.2BLN), 1.0955 (1BLN)

FIXED INCOME

In many ways it’s been more of the same for the mainstream 10 year benchmarks, but after following external leads in early trade due to Liffe’s later kick-off Gilts gradually caught up and overtook their peers to get within a tick of Wednesday’s 135.05 apex at one stage. No definitive or easy to pinpoint catalyst, but UK STIRs also eclipsed 3 month counterparts along the way to infer a more dovish BoE spin and/or heightened hard Brexit positioning. Meanwhile, Bunds have not bettered their previous Eurex best like 10-year USTs in the run up to a raft of US data, 7 year supply and Fed speak.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent prices are, once again, subdued on virus demand concerns as cases continue to rise and spread globally; currently, front-month futures are lower by around USD 1.0/bbl and remain just below the USD 48/bbl and USD 52/bbl marks. WTI is currently on track to post a weekly loss in excess of 10%, a loss which would be the largest weekly decline since December 2018 on a percentage term. Crude specific newsflow, away from the virus has been light, with the only pertinent comments stemming from Russian Energy Minister Novak that he wishes to increase co-operation with both Saudi Arabia and OPEC+; further pushing back on the talk of a rift within the cartel. In terms of notably commentary Gazprom have remarked that, because of the lack of clarity over demand, OPEC+ should wait a while longer before making a decision around adding to or extending production; which comes ahead of next week’s OPEC+ gathering. Turning to metals where spot gold is little changed on the day and has seen a much less volatile session than has occurred over the last few weeks; interestingly, the precious metal is currently little moved from the unchanged mark on a weekly basis in-spite of a range just shy of USD 65/oz at present. Elsewhere, copper prices are modestly softer and continued to be afflicted alongside other base metals on demand-side fears.

Russian Energy Minister Novak says Russia wants to continue cooperation with Saudi within the OPEC+ and bilaterally. (Newswires)

Norwegian Sovereign Wealth Fund: Q4 ROI was 5.1%, 2019 was 19.9%; held 70.8% in equities (Prev. 69.1%), 26.5% in fixed income (Prev. 28.2%) and real estate 2.7% (Prev. 2.8%). (Newswires)

subject: Italian Government says there are 528 confirmed cases of the coronavirus in Italy
analysis_details:
• Note, earlier the WHO did state that cases may be inflated due to mis-diagnosing
  • Previously has around 470 positive cases of the virus

subject: ECB's Schnabel says that nobody knows where the reversal rate is and it is not clear if we have reached it
content:
• Reversal rate is not one number, adding that it is moving all the time
  • Tiering has created further space

subject: UK sell GBP 400mln 1.75% 2057 Gilt: b/c 3.88x
BoE’s Cunliffe says the UK has weak domestic inflation, despite domestic cost pressures; question is how much of weak UK domestic inflation is cyclical against structural
content:
• Sees inflation coming from the UK labour market
  • We may be seeing a trend decline in UK corporate margins and profitability
  • We expect domestic cost pressures to feed through to inflation and push it slightly above target
  • Trend real interest rate is between zero and 1%
  • Can't explain very low rates entirely through the trend rate; there is an entrenched pessimism in the real interest rate curve
  • Should not rush into radical conclusions regarding monetary policy framework, there is policy space
  • If we have a shock, policy space should be used rapidly in order to avoid any liquidity traps

subject: UK Mandate: UK willing to trade on a no-deal basis with the EU if trade talks fail, want equivalent settlements to be carried out by June
content:
• Will be no role for the ECJ in any dispute mechanism
  • Should not require UK to follow EU standards
  • Should not, in any manner, constrict tax sovereignty
  • In line with the EU-Canadian agreement precedent, deal should recognise the right of each party to set their own labour priorities and adopt or modify tax laws
  • Agreement should include reciprocal commitments not to weaken/reduce the level of protection was is provided by labour laws/standards to encourage trade and/or investment
  • Should provide for streamlined customs arrangements covering all trade in EU goods
  • UK will not link access to its fishing waters to access EU markets
reaction_details: • Prior to the release of this we had been seeing some upside across Gillt June'20 futures as well as some downside in GBP with GBP/USD breaching 1.29 to the downside
analysis_details:
• Note, this was expected to be released at 11:15GMT
  • There was some speculation that in this mandate UK PM Johnson would walk back on some of his promises to the EU which have previously been agreed via the political decleration; with the most in focus being those around Northern Ireland
  • With one political journalist earlier in the session noting  "If the UK's opening position is to announce they won't abide by the promises they signed just last month, these negotiations are over before they begin," journalist Keating citing a EU Source

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

27th February 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly lower following a mixed Wall Street handover, as major indices faded gains heading into the latter part of the US session before the Dow and S&P dipped into negative territory – with the former’s losses tallying over 2000 points this week thus far. Furthermore, US equity futures trickled lower since reopen amid the rising virus cases outside China and with the first “community spread” reported in the States. ASX 200 (-0.8%) is mostly weighed on by its banking and base-metal miners, while some earnings-related movers were scattered across the index. Nikkei 225 (-2.0%) underperformed with downside led by manufacturing, automakers, and financials, whilst Panasonic shares slid over 4% after ending its solar partnership with Tesla. KOSPI (-0.7%) hit levels last seen in October last year as the index continued to be weighed on by the surging number of coronavirus cases in the country, alongside the surprise hold on rates by the BoK. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.9%) joined the regional stock rout as the energy and entertainment names added further to the losses seen this week, whilst Shanghai Comp (+0.4%) showed resilience and bucked the trend despite yet another PBoC inaction, as the rate of virus deaths in the country eased, the rate new cases steadied, and with further pledges from China to cushion the virus impact and stem the contagion.

HK and Virus headwinds expected to be transitory, but now believe it will take longer to achieve ROTE target of 10%; CEO says impact from COVID-19 will come in March and beyond. Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 27th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·       Asian equity markets traded mostly lower following a mixed Wall Street handover, US equity and DAX futures trade with heavy losses heading into the European open

·       US President Trump said we are ready to adapt and do whatever to tackle the virus outbreak, VP Pence was put in charge of the virus task force

·       First US coronavirus case of unknown origin confirmed in North California; CDC said it could be the first instance of “community spread”

·       Microsoft (MSFT) became the latest company to cut guidance due to coronavirus; shares fell 2% after market

·       In FX, DXY was softer overall, USD/JPY dipped below 110.00, KRW seesawed on surprise BoK hold and a jump in nCoV cases

·       Looking ahead, highlights include EZ Consumer Confidence (Final), Economic, Industrial & Services Sentiment, US Durable Goods, GDP (2nd Estimate), PCE Prices (Prelim), Pending Sales, Japanese CPI, Unemployment Rate & Retail Sales, ECB’s Lagarde, Lane, Panetta, Schnabel, de Guindos, BoE’s Carney, Fed’s Mester & Evans, Supply from Italy and US, Norwegian Gov’t Pension Fund Annual Report, UK Brexit Negotiating Mandate Released

·       Earnings include Ab InBev, Bayer, Persimmon

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE 

US President Trump said the risk to the American people from the virus is very low, we are ready to act, adapt and do whatever we have to, If congress wants to allocate more than USD 2.5bln for coronavirus, we’ll take it. Trump added that he has spoken to doctors and believe that the vaccine can be developed rapidly. The President announced that he will be putting VP Mike Pence in charge of US response to coronavirus. Trump acknowledged that Chinese President Xi is working very hard on the virus situation but noted that coronavirus could impact US GDP. US President Trump reiterated he thinks the stock markets will recover and puts some blame for the stock rout on the US Democratic debate. (Newswires) Trump Administration sees coronavirus as a serious threat with a fatality rate comparable to the flu, sources say. (Twitter) US Pentagon is mulling whether it may need additional funding to deal with the spread of COVID-19. (Newswires) US VP Pence is to lead a task force meeting on Thursday at 14:30ET/19:30GMT. (Newswires)

US National Institute of Allergy Infection Diseases Director gave a timeframe of 1 to 1.5 years for a usable vaccine. US Secretary of Health says we can expect to see more cases in the US, the degree of virus risk has the potential to change quickly. (Newswires)

First US coronavirus case of unknown origin confirmed in North California (Washington Post) CDC said that the COVID-19 case in California of unknown origin could be an instance of community spread, which would be the first time this has happened in the US. (Newswires) FDA official warned COVID-19 is "on the cusp" of being a pandemic. FDA official said a three-month estimate for COVID-19 vaccine to enter human trials could be too aggressive. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 334 more cases of new coronavirus thus far on February 26 vs. a total 284 on February 25; total cases now at 1595 and a 13th coronavirus-related death reported. (Yonhap) South Korea and US combined military exercises will be postponed "until further notice" amid coronavirus fears. (Yonhap) Japan's ruling party is reportedly considering an extra budget to tackle the virus outbreak, according to Nikkei. (Nikkei) China's Wang Yi has offered further help to Japan over virus controls. (Newswires) Germany has reported 9 new cases of coronavirus so far on February 26, whilst Demark reported its first case, according to BNO Newsroom. (Twitter)

China's Hubei province reported 409 new coronavirus cases and 26 additional deaths as of February 26 vs. 401 additional cases and 52 additional deaths on February 25, Total cases 65596 and deaths 2641. China reported an additional 433 coronavirus cases and 29 additional deaths as of February 26 vs. 406 additional cases and 52 deaths on February 25; Total China cases 78497 vs. Prev. 78064; Deaths 2744 vs. Prev. 2715. (Newswires)

US President Trump said now is not the right time to restrict travel from South Korea, Italy and other infected countries, but may impose restrictions at some point, but travel restrictions to China will not be loosened until the virus is no longer a problem. Trump said the US has plans on a larger scale quarantine if needed. (Newswires) US State Department raised the alert level for South Korea over the virus outbreak. (Newswires) IMF and World Bank are reportedly rethinking April 17-19 meeting amid coronavirus, according to sources. (Newswires)

Gilead (GILD) has initiated two Phase III studies of investigational antiviral Remdesivir for the treatment of coronavirus - studies in Asian countries to be in March. (Newswires) Kanagawa prefecture is said to have developed a faster virus test, according to TV Asahi. (Newswires)

Microsoft (MSFT) cut its Q3 personal computing segment revenue guidance due to coronavirus, sees supply chain returning to normal operations at a slower pace than previously expected. (Newswires) For reference, Co. has a 4.2% weighting in the DJIA, 4.9% in the S&P and 11.3% in the Nasdaq; Co. shares fell 2% after-market

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly lower following a mixed Wall Street handover, as major indices faded gains heading into the latter part of the US session before the Dow and S&P dipped into negative territory – with the former’s losses tallying over 2000 points this week thus far. Furthermore, US equity futures trickled lower since reopen amid the rising virus cases outside China and with the first “community spread” reported in the States. ASX 200 (-0.8%) is mostly weighed on by its banking and base-metal miners, while some earnings-related movers were scattered across the index. Nikkei 225 (-2.0%) underperformed with downside led by manufacturing, automakers, and financials, whilst Panasonic shares slid over 4% after ending its solar partnership with Tesla. KOSPI (-0.7%) hit levels last seen in October last year as the index continued to be weighed on by the surging number of coronavirus cases in the country, alongside the surprise hold on rates by the BoK. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.9%) joined the regional stock rout as the energy and entertainment names added further to the losses seen this week, whilst Shanghai Comp (+0.4%) showed resilience and bucked the trend despite yet another PBoC inaction, as the rate of virus deaths in the country eased, the rate new cases steadied, and with further pledges from China to cushion the virus impact and stem the contagion.

PBoC sets USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0215 vs. Exp. 7.0164 (Prev. 7.0126) (Newswires) PBOC skips open market operations for a daily net neutral position

The Bank of Korea surprisingly left its Base Rate on hold at 1.25% vs. expectations for a 25bps. The decision was not unanimous, prior dissenters Shin and Cho advocated a rate cut. The BoK also lowered its 2020 GDP forecast to 2.1% from 2.3%, whilst maintaining its inflation forecast for the year at 1.0%. BoK Governor Lee said the growth outlook assumes virus outbreak will not last too long, whilst also noting that South Korean Q1 growth could be negative. Governor Lee did state that the Central Bank has enough policy room to respond to growth risks if needed. Furthermore, the BoK stated they are to expand special loan programs by KRW 5tln to improve liquidity. (Newswires)

BoJ Board Member Kataoka said the BoJ is ready to ease without hesitation if needed, must deepen negative rates to make the shape of the yield curve more accommodative; Japan has no longer the momentum to reach its 2% goal. Kataoka added that there is room for BoJ to review its monetary policy framework and re-examine the effects of its policy, and noted that risks to economy tilted to the downside. (Newswires)

New Zealand Annual Trade Balance (Jan) -3.87B (Prev. -4.31B, Rev. -4.46B) (Newswires) New Zealand Exports (Jan) 4.73B (Prev. 5.54B, Rev. 5.50B) New Zealand Imports (Jan) 5.07B (Prev. 5.0B, Rev. 5.12B)

S&P affirmed New Zealand rating at "AA"; outlook revised to "positive" from "stable". (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson will on Thursday scrap previous commitments to Brussels as he publishes Britain’s goals for a trade deal with the EU, setting up a row over the so-called “level playing field” on which the two sides will do business, FT reported. Johnson’s negotiating mandate will insist that Britain should enjoy full control over its own rules in areas such as state aid, labour laws, and the environment, while also setting out a tough stance on fishing rights. (FT)

SNB's Machler reiterated negative rates are a necessary tool and SNB is prepared to intervene in the FX market. (Newswires)

FX

In FX, DXY traded on a softer footing on either side of 99.000 after the index saw some weakness during US President Trump’s coronavirus presser, which highlighted that a usable vaccine would take 12-18 months to produce, while the President also noted that US GDP could be impacted – G10 pairs largely moved in tandem with the Greenback throughout the session. EUR/USD briefly gained impetus above 1.0900 before stabilising around the figure, while GBP/USD reclaimed 1.2900 to the upside as traders look forward to PM Johnson’s unveiling of his negotiating mandate with the EU, which is expected to set out a tough stance on fishing rights. Similarly, Antipodeans moved in lockstep with the Dollar, Kiwi largely side-lined a narrowing annual trade balance deficit amid a decline in exports, whilst the Aussie ignored dismal Private Capex data. AUD/USD gained modest ground north of 0.6550 and remained above its most recent 11yr low of 0.6542. NZD/USD found mild support at ~0.6280 which coincides with the Sep 27th and Oct 17th lows from last year, although gains in the Kiwi seemed hampered after the NZ Finance Minister stated that coronavirus will have a serious short-term impact on its economy. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were uneventful for a large part of the session with the former dictated by its base currency, although modest strength was seen flowing into the Yen towards the latter part of the APAC session, which prompted USD/JPY and EUR/JPY to test 110.00 and 120.00 to the downside respectively. Finally, KRW garnered attention after the BoK surprisingly left its Base Rate unchanged at 1.25%, against rising calls for a 25bps cut – initially instigating gains in the Won. However, a surge in nCoV cases in the country saw the KRW pare back all its BoK-induced gains and reverse course. USD/KRW eclipsed 1216 to the upside vs. a BoK low of ~1209.25.

New Zealand Finance Minister Robertson said the NZ economy is in a strong position to respond to the virus, but it will have a serious impact short-term. (Newswires)

Banxico cut 2020 growth to between 0.5% and 1.5% (Prev. 0.8% and 1.8%); raises inflation forecast for Q4 2020 to 3.2% (Prev. 3.0%). Expects headline inflation to reach its 3% target in Q1 2021. Banxico also cut 2021 economic growth to between 1.1% and 2.1% (Prev. 1.3% and 2.3%). (Newswires)

COMMODITIES 

WTI and Brent front-month futures continued their sell-off in overnight trade amid growing concerns over the rising coronavirus cases, with cases outside surpassing those within China for the first time. WTI Apr’20 briefly dipped below 48/bbl whilst Brent May’20 found an overnight base at USD 52.00/bbl. In terms of forecasts, Goldman Sachs Equity Research lowered their Brent H1 and FY20 views to USD 57/bbl (Prev. USD 63/bbl) and USD 60/bbl (Prev. USD 63/bbl) respectively, citing near term demand uncertainty due to coronavirus. Elsewhere, spot gold retained an underlying bid as stocked continued to slide, with the yellow metal back to USD 1650/oz levels (vs. low USD 1639/oz) heading into the European session ahead of yesterday’s 1655/oz high. Meanwhile, copper prices traded choppily but remained modestly firmer as the weaker USD kept prices afloat.

Libyan oil production stood at 136k BPD as of February 25th, previously at 122k BPD as of February 23rd, according to NOC. (Newswires)

US 

* US T-NOTE FUTURES SETTLED 6+ TICKS HIGHER AT 133-10+. The coronavirus' spreads set the tone for risk markets, and while the direction was meandering in early trade, ultimately, yields are lower across the curve at settlement, with fresh record lows seen for 10-year yields, while 30s matched Tuesday's low. Major curve spreads were boased towards steepening, with 5s30s +6bps as traders wrapped up for the day. Today's auction of 5s was average, which by the standards of Tuesday's 2s auction means it was reasonable; the sale tailed and saw the lowest yield at a 5s auction since September 2016. Tomorrow the US will sell 7s; the 7s sector trades cheap in asset swap versus older 7s, SocGen's analysts observe, though trades fair on the fly against 5s and 10s. SocGen thinks the auction will be expensive on an outright basis, given the WI is trading below all stop-out rates since 2013. The bank notes that the 2s7s curve has flattened meaningfully this year, and that has seen 7s richen on the curve. SocGen says it has a negative bias ahead of the auction.

subject: PREVIEW: BOK rate decision on Thursday 27th February 2020 at 0100GMT/0900HKT
content:
OVERVIEW: 

  • 16 out of 26 economists polled by Reuters expect the Bank of Korea to lower rates by 25bps to a record low of 1.00% (marking the third cut in its easing cycle), while 10 respondents see the Central Bank holding rates at 1.25%; 20 out of 26 analysts see a 25bps reduction by May.

EVOLUTION OF EXPECTATIONS: 

  • Calls for easing were largely bolstered amid the coronavirus outbreak, as economic prospects for the trade-reliant country faces hurdles in light of supply disruptions and dampened global demand. In January, only 20% of the economists polled at the time expected a February rate reduction, provided the upbeat Central Bank statement at the January meeting - due to easing trade tensions between US and China coupled with a then resilient domestic environment.

DATA: 

  • Early February trade data showed a significant decline in Chinese demand as the spill-over from the virus outbreak in China started to materialise on South Korean export figures. Furthermore, the fourth-largest Asian economy grew at 2.0% in 2019, the slowest pace in 10-years, which came despite two rates cuts and a significant increase to the country’s budget. Moreover, domestic demand has cooled in February, reflected by the latest Consumer Sentiment data which fell from 104.2 to 96.9 – marking the lowest reading in six months and the sharpest fall since mid-2015.

GOVERNMENT MEASURES: 

  • The South Korean government has taken measures to stem the spread of the virus domestically following the mammoth rise in cases over the weekend, which prompted Seoul to raise its virus alert level to the “highest”. President Moon has also called on the government to draft a supplementary budget as soon as possible, whilst also implementing a containment policy on the largest infected area, Daegu. The country has also delayed the start of school by a week, whilst also urging citizens to avoid densely populated congregations. BoK Governor Lee held an emergency meeting on Monday to discuss the impact of the virus outbreak, albeit there were no signals of any planned policy action.

RATE ANNOUNCEMENT TWEAKS: 

  • The coronavirus outbreak has also changed the way the Central Bank will deliver its rate decision on Thursday. The decision, typically announced by an official, will instead be delivered via a text message and email amid precaution for the safety of the press, according to a statement by the Bank. Further, the live presser will instead be streamed on Facebook and YouTube with only representatives of the press permitted to attend the live event. At the Q&A, journalists and other reporters will have to submit questions in advance via their smartphones
